summary: VP16 is an abundant 65-kDa virion phosphoprotein synthesized late in infection. it acts during the earliest stages of infection to stimulate transcription of the viral IE genes. VP16 is targeted to the TAATGARATTC consensus sequence found in IE promoters. ts 2203 mutation blocks virus assembly, arguing that VP16 plays an essential role in virion maturation. the innate immune system is the first line of defense in response to virus infection. IFN binds to specific IFN receptors in an autocrine or paracrine manner. this leads to the formation of the IFN-stimulated gene factor 3 (ISGF3) transcription complex. transcriptional factors IRF-3 and IRF-7 play important roles in virus-induced type I interferon gene activation following virus infection (15, 16) VP16 blocked both infection-induced and tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-)-induced activation of the NF-B promoter and expression of NF-B-dependent genes.
